body.p: Respected and Dear Sir,

I hope that you are home by this time and that your trip trough the states
will have had the effect of improving your health and of strenghtening and
renewing your energies to future spiritual labor.

I am in possession of your kind letter dated St. Louis Dec. 18th but fearing the
answer would not reach you in time, as there were no mail-boats g running,
I thought it advisable to omit it.

With this letter I mail one to the Asmonean containing a statement of
the proceedings taken in your behalf, while in this city. I will give you
on the other side the substance of my correspondence, which would have
reached New York long before this, were it not for an approval it had
to undergo at our Board of Trustees.

I am inclined to believe that all your subscribers would like to receive
the Occident for January, as they, or the most of them, are desirou
desirous to know something of your doings in other places also. I
would therefore humbly advise you to begin with the next number,
if you deem it expedient and till? up to spirit charge your abane?.

Please let me hear from you, as soon you are arrived in Pha
my wife requested me to give you her best respects.
Straus, Lirhten?, Lowensohn, Oberudarfer and all your friends—and
there are a good many—return their heartfelt regard and esteem
to you.

May the Lord grant you many years of uninterrupted health and happi
ness, to enable you to reap the fruits of your sowing.
Your devoted friend and obedient servant

for the Occident, by request of the Congregation Adath Isral
Louisville
Presentation of a Silver Goblet
to

Louisville Ky. Revd Isaac Leeser visited this city. He arrived here on the morning
of the 11th of December and as soon as this fact became known, a meeting
of the Board was convened by order of our respected President, M. Straus
Esqr., in consequence of which the Revd Is. Leeser received a form at invitation
to lecture on Sabbath morning following. The Revd Gentleman kindly assen
ted and delighted his numerous audience in a very able and luminous
discourse.—On Sunday afternoon a general meeting was called
and after stating the object of the meeting the following Resolutions
were unanimously adopted:

Resolved, that as small token of the appreciation in which the Revd
Isaac Leeser is held by this Congregation, he be presented with a Silver
Goblet bearing a suitable inscription.

Resolved, that the presentation shall take place on Monday evening,
the 8th of Dec. in the presence of the whole Congregation, and that the
Revd Gentleman be invited to attend.

In accordance with these Resolutions the members of the Congre
gation repaired on Monday evening to the Kofsath? Hotel, the ap
pointed place of meeting. Mr. M. Straus presided and, as usual,
after stating the object of the convocation selected a committee
of five to draft Resolutions suitable for the occasion—and
the following Resolutions were proposed, seconded and unanimously
carried: (there follow the Resolutions, a copy of which were handed to you.)

Signed, B. H. Gotthelf, Z. A. Jefsel, B. Sachs, L. Silberman, H. Stern}Committee
After the unanimous adoption of the foregoing Resolutions, a Committee
was appointed to request the Revd I. L. to join the meeting. When
he made his appearance, these Resolutions were read to him by the

Revd B H. Gotthelf, the Chairman of the Committee, after which M. Straus Esqr
by presenting the Goblet spoke very feelingly in substance as fellows:—

„Revd Sir, It affords me great and infinite pleasure to have been se
„lected as the organ of the religious body over which I have the honor
„to preside, to request your acceptance of this goblet, which I hold in
„my hand—and in doing so, I must ask your kind indulgence if
„you find, that I am not able to do justice to so interesting a
„subject, not being accustomed to public speaking.

„ This Silver Cup is not given to you to value the precious metal
„it contains, nor is it given as a renumeration for the very efficient
„and able services you so voluntarily rendered us on Sabbath morning,
„but Revd Sir, it is presented to you as a small token of the high
„respect we entertain towards one, whose best years have been spent
„in the unswerving, unwavering and unflinching duty of defending the
„rights and privileges of our coreligionists; whose daily task has been to
„spread abroad and at home a true knowledge of our Holy Faith and
„of the duties incumbent on us as a nation to which such glorious
„promises are held out.

„ When we reflect, Revd Sir, on all that you have done so maintain
„the true dignity of Israel, so implant in our youth the „fear of the Lord
„the beginning of wisdom", to instil among our fellow-citizens a current appre
„ciation of the Jewish character—, the numerous works that have ema
„nated from your pen—: we cannot but admire the versatility of your
„talents, and to hail with sentiments of profound pleasure the opportunity
„you have so kindly afforded us of becoming acquainted personally with
„one, whose well-earned fame is widely spread over the four corners of
„the globe; and I speak but the united sentiments of this congregation, when
„I assure you, that we will allways look up to you as our guide, as our teacher.

„ May He, in whose Holy service you so faithfully ministered and for
„whose Glory you still labor, retain you ever in His Holy Keeping; may
„He strenghten you to complete your task; may Health, Long Life
„and Prosperity be long accorded you; and may a ? of
„Glory await you in the realms above"!—

The inscription was then read: „Presented by the Congregation
„Adath Israel Louisville Ky, to the Revd Isaac Leeser, the Champion of
„Jewish Rights—Dec. 8th 1851—5612.

after which the Revd Gentleman feelingly replied in a harangue which
much affected his attentive and numerous auditors.

P.S. Dear Sir, you are permitted, to alter, ammend, abridge ?
according to your judgement.-
yours
